snippet.textDisplay: In all for technology progress but within reason. Google is basically trying to complicate something that gamers don't actually need. Now you have to have a good internet to play your games offline, pay for a new "steam", and pay again for the games and pay for new hardware when all you need is to simply purchase a hardware and game and play.  Totally uncessary, I really hope that gaming for streaming don't work. Nobody needs a gaming platform to take everywhere, and if you do purchase a gamer notebook or a Switch.

snippet.textDisplay: Stadia might be crap but there is no denying it's the future whether we like it or not - Google can't give up on this. I think they are doing the "move fast and break stuff" and staking their claim. They have the $ and though I wouldn't buy this, I would be really disappointed if they gave up. They should really partner with a tried and true gaming company - they should be a software/platform provider but in a position where they are forced to consult with gamers.

They should really partner with a tried and true gaming company - they should be a software/platform provider but in a position where they are forced to consult with gamers.

snippet.textDisplay:
I love stadia. It really helped me incorporate video games back into my life for the first time in years. It's all because of the pick up and play aspect to it.

And for all the people mentioning the hotel comment, I have played stadia at many hotels and family houses with terrible internet and was able to play just fine. Your mileage may vary of course but it seems to work well on a lot less than I expected.

snippet.textDisplay:
So I've been playing my Stadia pretty regularly. I'm one of those people who have an One X, PS4 Pro and Switch. I haven't purchased any games on it, only been playing the free one's so far (mostly Tomb Raider). I have to say I'm pretty impressed with the service. Granted I have gig speed where I play, so I haven't had any streaming issues.


On the positive side:


It's nice to not have to make space for another console plus accessories (Controller charger,external hard drive, more 4k HDMI splitters, finding yet another outlet, running more HDMI cables) just to be only able to play it on one tv. I have a few Chrome-cast Ultra's so moving room to room is pretty nice only having to reconnect the controller.


Getting used to launching the games from your phone takes a little time, but that being said any recordings or in game screenshots taken record to the app on your phone so they are easy to get to and share. (I don't do this a lot but it is a nice thing.)


The one negative I really have:


Is in moving the controllers room to room. Yes, being able to use more than one TV is nice (granted you have the Chromecast Ultra's) but the re connection time from pressing the code given to you on the screen and from the controller is just terrible. I find myself being able to enter the sequence almost 20 times with waiting in between until it actually connects. After connecting though I haven't run into any in game lag with pressing buttons causing the same issue.


I think some things Google needs to do with this to compete are:


Getting a big Triple A exclusive that can be branched into something long term. Maybe they put up the money for Anthem to be made to what it was actually supposed to be, then get it out to those who are premium members to get the word going about the system.


The controller connection time needs to be fixed. Since that's just annoying.


An offline mode would be nice. Even if your only downloading the single player part of the game, nothing to do with anything online. I know there's a lot about just streaming the game, and console's you don't need great internet, but you really still do. My buddy is a real casual XBOX player, but it's even worse when he go's and connects his XBOX online and to play anything it requires a 2 day system update to be downloaded (download speed limitations). So no console can really ever only be offline now a days.
snippet.textOriginal:
So I've been playing my Stadia pretty regularly. I'm one of those people who have an One X, PS4 Pro and Switch. I haven't purchased any games on it, only been playing the free one's so far (mostly Tomb Raider). I have to say I'm pretty impressed with the service. Granted I have gig speed where I play, so I haven't had any streaming issues. 


On the positive side:


It's nice to not have to make space for another console plus accessories (Controller charger,external hard drive, more 4k HDMI splitters, finding yet another outlet, running more HDMI cables) just to be only able to play it on one tv. I have a few Chrome-cast Ultra's so moving room to room is pretty nice only having to reconnect the controller. 


Getting used to launching the games from your phone takes a little time, but that being said any recordings or in game screenshots taken record to the app on your phone so they are easy to get to and share.  (I don't do this a lot but it is a nice thing.)


The one negative I really have: 


Is in moving the controllers room to room. Yes, being able to use more than one TV is nice (granted you have the Chromecast Ultra's) but the re connection time from pressing the code given to you on the screen and from the controller is just terrible. I find myself being able to enter the sequence almost 20 times with waiting in between until it actually connects.  After connecting though I haven't run into any in game lag with pressing buttons causing the same issue. 


I think some things Google needs to do with this to compete are:


Getting a big Triple A exclusive that can be branched into something long term. Maybe they put up the money for Anthem to be made to what it was actually supposed to be, then get it out to those who are premium members to get the word going about the system. 


The controller connection time needs to be fixed. Since that's just annoying.


An offline mode would be nice. Even if your only downloading the single player part of the game, nothing to do with anything online. I know there's a lot about just streaming the game, and console's you don't need great internet, but you really still do. My buddy is a real casual XBOX player, but it's even worse when he go's and connects his XBOX online and to play anything it requires a 2 day system update to be downloaded (download speed limitations). So no console can really ever only be offline now a days.

snippet.textDisplay: In my personal experience I've enjoyed playing Stadia, and the tech itself is astonishing. My only issue is the lack of games. I find myself going back to my Xbox or PS4 to play games like NHL and Call of duty which Stadia doesn't offer. They've promised over 100 new games for the platform this year as well as 10 new Stadia exclusives, but these are all promises for the future which I have yet to see.
snippet.textOriginal: In my personal experience I've enjoyed playing Stadia, and the tech itself is astonishing. My only issue is the lack of games. I find myself going back to my Xbox or PS4 to play games like NHL and Call of duty which Stadia doesn't offer. They've promised over 100 new games for the platform this year as well as 10 new Stadia exclusives, but these are all promises for the future which I have yet to see.

snippet.textDisplay: As a hardcore gamer who plays mostly jrpgs, Stadia is the last thing I want for myself and the games industry. I like physical games, books, strat guides, movies, music CDs, etc. I like collectors editions. From older Working Designs games to current games. Digital media is a joke. If you can't hold it in your hand, you don't own it. Streaming only - like Stadia, is just the next step beyond the digital bullshit. Fuck Stadia.
snippet.textOriginal: As a hardcore gamer who plays mostly jrpgs, Stadia is the last thing I want for myself and the games industry. I like physical games, books, strat guides, movies, music CDs, etc. I like collectors editions. From older Working Designs games to current games. Digital media is a joke. If you can't hold it in your hand, you don't own it. Streaming only - like Stadia, is just the next step beyond the digital bullshit. Fuck Stadia.

snippet.textDisplay:
My Switch takes up about as much space as a Stadia controller. It also lets me own games without depending on an internet connection, it lets me play with friends, it offers me exclusive games from franchises I like and once it is no longer supported by the developer, I will actually keep everything I bought.


Stadia offers me none of that and instead asks me to pay full price, for a rental that will definitely not run as intended on my internet connection, so the product fails to appeal to me or provide something new. The tech is cool, sure but like with VR that is not a reason for me to spend money on it.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: What is the point of buying a game when you can do the same on PC and consoles?? People was looking for a subscription service like Xbox game pass or Playstation Play where a fix price annually or monthly gets you unlimited access. But if you pay for the $130 console + monthly subscription and requires to buy the game itself, this is redundantly expensive and actually just plain stupid. Also it depends solely on your internet speed and a chromecast....people would rather pay $60 for console's online services and get unlimited access to games where you download and doesn't require constant access.
snippet.textOriginal: What is the point of buying a game when you can do the same on PC and consoles?? People was looking for a subscription service like Xbox game pass or Playstation Play where a fix price annually or monthly gets you unlimited access. But if you pay for the $130 console + monthly subscription and requires to buy the game itself, this is redundantly expensive and actually just plain stupid. Also it depends solely on your internet speed and a chromecast....people would rather pay $60 for console's online services and get unlimited access to games where you download and doesn't require constant access.

snippet.textDisplay: I live in a rural area 20 miles away from a rural town. The only reliable internet is via tethering my cell phone to my computer. If I'm really lucky, I might get 40 kbps. It typically takes me an hour to download a gigabyte of data. Chances are good that I'll be moving to an even more rural area soon. There's no way in hell I'll ever be able to use Stadia.
snippet.textOriginal: I live in a rural area 20 miles away from a rural town. The only reliable internet is via tethering my cell phone to my computer. If I'm really lucky, I might get 40 kbps. snippet.textDisplay:
Another thing to note is the amount of data streamed. IT'S A LOT of data throughout a month if you're a daily gamer. My internet service has a data ceiling of 1 terabyte. I can reach one terabyte in just a couple of weeks and there's high service fees for unlimited data, it's like $49.99 a month just for unlimited data. For game streaming services to really flourish, companies will need to work with service providers to alleviate a lot of the costs.

Simply put, it's not affordable for a lot of people to stream as much data as it takes for the average gamer.
snippet.textOriginal:
Another thing to note is the amount of data streamed.  IT'S A LOT of data throughout a month if you're a daily gamer.  My internet service has a data ceiling of 1 terabyte.  I can reach one terabyte in just a couple of weeks and there's high service fees for unlimited data, it's like $49.99 a month just for unlimited data.  For game streaming services to really flourish, companies will need to work with service providers to alleviate a lot of the costs.  

Simply put, it's not affordable for a lot of people to stream as much data as it takes for the average gamer.

snippet.textDisplay:
Stadia can't prosper in a world where Shadow tech exists, you stream a powerful pc without having to buy anything other than the subscription.
No limit to what you can play as you can just use your steam account.
The experience is smooth at as long as you have a good internet (buttery smooth with 80mb/s bandwidth)
